intro: Acacia adoxa var. adoxa, commonly known as the narrow-leaved wattle, is a shrub native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its slender, often spiny stems and bipinnate leaves composed of numerous small, oval-shaped leaflets. The plant produces bright yellow flowers in globular or cylindrical inflorescences, typically during the summer months. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. The species is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens for its striking floral display.

Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees known for their distinctive, often thorned appearance and nitrogen-fixing capabilities. This variant of the species is commonly found in the arid and semi-arid regions of these areas. It thrives in sandy soils and is often seen in open woodlands and shrublands. The plant is well adapted to the harsh climatic conditions of its native range. It plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for native wildlife.

It is commonly found in disturbed areas such as roadsides, abandoned fields, and urban landscapes.
